items.title: More than 350 structures lost to Vic bushfires as locals assess damage
items.description: More than 350 structures have been destroyed by several bushfires burning across Victoria, authorities say, as residents return home to take stock of the devastation.

items.title: Rubber bullets to 'machine guns': Why Iranians fear the aftermath of an internet blackout
items.description: Iranians have endured a blackout but for many the fears of atrocities committed by the Khamenei regime are real and based on reports of machine guns being used.

items.title: Imam thanks police after alleged roadside assault in Melbourne
items.description: An imam who was allegedly the victim of racial abuse during a roadside assault has thanked the police who helped him and his wife, and urged Australians to reject hate, Islamophobia and antisemitism.

items.title: Adelaide Writers' Week 'hangs in the balance' as Jacinda Ardern joins list of authors boycotting event
items.description: The future of Adelaide Writers' Week (AWW) remains unclear as Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah says she is considering her legal options. Former New Zealand prime minister Jacinda Ardern is among those who will no longer appear at the event.

items.title: Wagner Moura becomes first Brazilian man to win Golden Globe

featured_image.name: Wagner Moura Wins Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Drama

items.description:
Brazilian actor Wagner Moura made Golden Globe history on Sunday night, becoming the first Brazilian man to win Best Actor in a Drama for his performance in "The Secret Agent," a political thriller set during Brazil's 1977 military dictatorship. The film also captured the Best Non-English Language Motion Picture award, cementing a triumphant night for Brazilian cinema at the Beverly Hilton.

"I was not prepared for this because I thought I was too old," Moura, 49, said during his acceptance speech, as reported by the Los Angeles Times[1]. The actor, who arrived on the red carpet in a white double-breasted jacket alongside his partner of nearly 30 years, Sandra Delgado, thanked his wife first in his remarks[2][3].

items.title: Danish PM says Greenland feud at a 'decisive moment' after new Trump threats
items.description: Donald Trump says controlling Greenland is crucial for US national security and he has suggested using force to seize the Arctic territory.

items.title: PM recalls parliament to introduce hate speech and gun laws
items.description: Anthony Albanese has recalled parliament early to deal with sweeping hate speech and gun laws in the wake of the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: Japan launches first deep-sea rare earth mission amid China export curbs

featured_image.name: Japan to begin extracting deep-sea rare earths next year ...

items.description:
A Japanese research vessel departed Monday for a remote Pacific atoll to begin the world's first attempt to extract rare earths from deep-sea mud, as Tokyo accelerates efforts to reduce its dependence on China following Beijing's latest export restrictions.

The deep-sea scientific drilling ship Chikyu set sail from the port city of Shizuoka bound for Minamitori Island, approximately 1,900 kilometers southeast of Tokyo, for a month-long mission to retrieve mineral-rich sediment from depths of 6,000 meters, according to Reuters[1][2]. The voyage marks a first-of-its-kind effort to continuously lift rare-earth material from such depths to a ship.

items.title: Golden Globes key moments: Chalamet bests Dicaprio, Rose Byrne shouts out her bearded dragon
items.description: This year's Golden Globes saw hits and misses for Australia, last-minute snubs and a humbled Timothée Chalamet.

items.title: 'This won't end well': US Fed Reserve chair facing criminal probe
items.description: The US attorney's office in the District of Columbia has opened a criminal investigation into Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve.

items.title: Iran protest death toll reaches 544, over 10,600 arrested

featured_image.name: Death Toll Grows as Nationwide Protests Rock Iran for a ...

items.description:
Nationwide protests in Iran have entered their third week, with the death toll rising to at least 544 as security forces intensify a violent crackdown on demonstrators calling for the end of the Islamic Republic, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency[1]. The unrest, which has spread to 185 cities across all 31 provinces, represents one of the most serious challenges to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's regime since the 1979 revolution[2][3].

HRANA reported Sunday that more than 10,600 people have been arrested since protests erupted on December 28, when Iran's currency plummeted to historic lows against the U.S. dollar[4][1]. The agency, which has a history of accurate reporting during previous Iranian unrest, confirmed 490 protester deaths and 48 security force fatalities, though the actual toll may be higher due to a nationwide internet blackout imposed January 8[2][5].

President Donald Trump has been briefed on military strike options for Iran and warned Tehran he would hit the regime "very, very hard where it hurts" if it continues killing protesters[6][7]. Iran's parliament speaker responded by threatening that U.S. troops and Israel would become "legitimate targets" if America intervenes militarily[8][4].

items.title: Exiled prince says he's preparing to return to Iran

featured_image.name: Reza Pahlavi Seeks to Re-emerge as a Reference Figure Amid ...

items.description:
Reza Pahlavi, the U.S.-based son of Iran's last shah, has declared he is "preparing to return to Iran" to lead a democratic transition as anti-regime protests enter their third week, marking a significant shift from passive supporter to active opposition leader attempting to direct a movement that has left at least 538 people dead[1][2][3].

The 63-year-old announced his readiness to return on January 10, telling Fox News he would lead the transition "to make sure that in full transparency, people have an opportunity to elect their leaders freely and to decide their own future"[4]. His calls for coordinated demonstrations at 8 p.m. local time on January 8 and 9 drew large crowds to the streets of Tehran and other cities, with protesters chanting "Long live the shah" and "Pahlavi will return"[5][6][7].

Pahlavi has moved beyond issuing statements from exile to providing tactical guidance, urging demonstrators to "seize and hold city centers," stay together on main streets, and maintain discipline[6][7]. He has also called for nationwide strikes among energy and transportation workers, seeking to apply economic pressure on the Islamic Republic[8]. Videos verified by monitoring groups showed thousands responding to his appeals despite a nationwide internet blackout imposed by authorities[5][2].

items.title: Von der Leyen backs Iran protesters, condemns crackdown

featured_image.name: Von der Leyen condemns violent crackdown on Iranian protesters

items.description:
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen expressed full support for anti-government protesters in Iran on January 10, condemning the violent crackdown by authorities and calling for the immediate release of detained demonstrators and restoration of internet access[1][2][3][4][5][6].

"Tehran's streets, and cities around the world, echo with the footsteps of Iranian women and men demanding freedom," von der Leyen wrote on social media[2][3][6]. "Europe stands fully behind them. We unequivocally condemn the violent repression of these legitimate demonstrations. Those responsible will be remembered on the wrong side of history."[3][4][6]

The statement comes as Iran faces its most widespread unrest since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, according to observers[7][8]. Protests erupted December 28 after the Iranian rial collapsed to over 1.4 million against the U.S. dollar, triggering demonstrations by Tehran bazaar merchants that quickly spread to at least 27 provinces[9][7][10][11].

Human rights groups report escalating violence under a nationwide internet blackout imposed January 8[12][13][14]. The Human Rights Activists in Iran documented at least 538 deaths, including 490 protesters and 48 security forces members, as of January 10[15]. The organization's data, based on activist networks inside the country, has proven accurate in previous unrest[16].

items.title: Man fronts court over duct taped vest near Bondi Beach
items.description: A man allegedly carrying a vest covered in duct-taped objects in Bondi has been arrested and charged by NSW Police, with his vest examined by the bomb disposal unit and deemed safe.

items.title: Iran protest death toll surpasses 500 under internet blackout

featured_image.name: Five things you need to know about protests in Iran

items.description:
Two weeks of nationwide protests in Iran have left more than 500 people dead as authorities intensified their crackdown under the cover of a near-total internet blackout, according to rights groups monitoring the unrest that has evolved into one of the most serious challenges to the Islamic Republic's theocratic government in years.

The U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency reported Sunday that at least 538 people have been killed, including 490 protesters and 48 security personnel[1][2][3]. More than 10,600 people have been arrested[1][2][4][3]. The Norway-based Iran Human Rights organization separately documented 192 deaths, warning the actual toll could be significantly higher as the ongoing communications blackout has made verification increasingly difficult[5][6].

The protests erupted on December 28 following the collapse of Iran's currency, the rial, which now trades at over 1.4 million to one U.S. dollar as the country's economy buckles under international sanctions[4][3][7]. What began as demonstrations over economic hardship has transformed into direct challenges to Iran's theocratic regime, with protesters chanting "Death to Khamenei" in reference to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei[8][9].

items.title: More than the US and UK, the Taliban has an issue with Australia
items.description: The Taliban's chief spokesman agreed to an unscripted, sit-down interview with me, there was just one non-negotiable condition, writes Meghna Bali.

items.title: Denmark to meet US on Greenland as Trump threats escalate

featured_image.name: Greenland elections are dominated by independence and Trump's interest in the island

items.description:
Denmark confirmed Sunday that Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen will meet with US Secretary of State Marco Rubio next week to discuss Greenland, as tensions escalate over President Donald Trump's repeated threats to take control of the Arctic territory[1][2].

"We are at a crossroads," Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said during a party conference, according to the Ritzau news agency[1][2]. The meeting comes after Denmark and Greenland requested talks with Rubio following intensifying rhetoric from the Trump administration, which has refused to rule out military force to acquire the mineral-rich island[3][4][5].

Trump said Friday that the US would "do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," adding that if America doesn't act, "Russia or China will take over Greenland"[6][7][8]. The White House confirmed Tuesday it is "discussing a range of options" to acquire Greenland, with press secretary Karoline Leavitt stating that "utilizing the U.S. military is always an option"[9][10].

items.title: Britain weighs Greenland deployment as Trump threatens seizure

featured_image.name: British troops land 'in force' in Arctic region - UK Defence Journal

items.description:
British Prime Minister Keir Starmer is weighing military options in Greenland following escalating threats by US President Donald Trump to seize the Danish territory, with UK officials pursuing an urgent diplomatic strategy to defuse the most serious NATO crisis in the alliance's history.

Trump declared Friday that the United States would "do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," refusing to rule out military force to acquire the semi-autonomous Arctic island[1][2]. The Daily Mail reported Sunday that Trump has ordered special forces commanders to draw up invasion plans, though senior military officials are reportedly resisting the directive as unlawful[3][4].

The Telegraph reported Saturday that military planners are developing proposals for a potential NATO mission to Greenland that could involve British troops, warships and aircraft[5][6]. Downing Street has held discussions with German and French counterparts in recent days about deploying forces to demonstrate that Europe can address Arctic security concerns, according to British officials[7][5].

items.title: Iran protest death toll exceeds 500 amid crackdown, rights group says

featured_image.name: Iran cuts internet as protest movement against regime grows

items.description:
The death toll from two weeks of anti-government protests in Iran has climbed above 500, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency, as authorities impose a nationwide internet blackout and threaten demonstrators with the death penalty.

HRANA reported Sunday that 490 protesters and 48 security force members have been killed since demonstrations erupted on December 28, with approximately 10,000 people arrested[1][2][3][4]. Reuters could not independently verify the figures, and Iranian authorities have not released official casualty counts[1][2][3]. Some reports suggest the actual toll may be far higher, with one Tehran doctor telling TIME that at least 217 deaths had been recorded across six hospitals in the capital alone[5].

Medical staff at hospitals in Tehran, Rasht, and Shiraz described facilities overwhelmed by the wounded and dead. A hospital worker in Tehran told the BBC that casualties were so numerous that "there wasn't enough space in the morgue; the bodies were placed on top of one another"[6][7]. Another medic reported security forces firing "direct shots to the heads of the young people, to their hearts as well"[6][7]. BBC Persian verified that approximately 70 bodies were brought to Poursina Hospital in Rasht on Friday night, exceeding morgue capacity[7][8].

items.title: Iran warns US bases, Israel are 'legitimate targets'

featured_image.name: Iran warns Israel, US military and shipping centers would be ...

items.description:
Iran's parliament speaker issued a stark warning Sunday that American military bases across the Middle East and Israel would be considered "legitimate targets" if the United States launches strikes against the Islamic Republic, as President Donald Trump weighs military options to support anti-government protesters.

Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf, speaking during a heated parliamentary session broadcast on state television, told lawmakers that Tehran would not limit itself to retaliatory strikes. "In the event of an attack on Iran, both the occupied territory and all American military centers, bases and ships in the region will be our legitimate targets," he said, using Iran's term for Israel[1][2][3]. "We do not consider ourselves limited to reacting after the action and will act based on any objective signs of a threat."

As Qalibaf spoke, lawmakers rushed the parliament dais chanting "Death to America," marking a sharp escalation in tensions[1][4].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
